column1: Migration and Building Culture: Transformation of Building through Individual and Collective Immigration ¤ Since antiquity, migration movements have had a special significance for the change of building art and technology. They can be triggered, for example, by wars, political repression, voluntary decisions, or economic pressure. Again and again, cultural imprints, transformation, and displacement processes occur, whose results illustrate the stability or adaptability of a society and its building culture. The publication brings together contributions from archaeology, the history of building and construction technology, monument conservation, as well as art and architectural history. In case studies spanning epochs, the mechanisms are examined that have led to the transformation of building as a result of individual and collective immigration.

Perspectives of Mining Heritage in Museums: Networking, Digitalization, Research ¤ The essays published in this volume, taken from a 2017 conference at the German Mining Museum in Bochum, examine mining heritage with regard to museumization, digitalization, restoration, and object research. At the same time, the volume reflects the diversity of mining’s historical legacy, which extends from associations to large museums of technology. The publication contains the contributions of a conference held at the end of 2017 by the Montanhistorisches Dokumentationszentrum (montan.dok) at the German Mining Museum in Bochum, which aimed to bring together representatives from various museums and museum institutions to discuss collections and objects in the context of museumization, digitalization, restoration, and object research. The contributions address this broad range of topics and explore the possibilities of a methodically reflected mining history. This is done with regard to object research and the use of object-related archival sources, as well as in terms of the presentation of object-related research in the digital world. The book is therefore primarily aimed at researchers in the field of mining and technology history, as well as those who are generally concerned with a material-based culture of remembrance.

Paul Bonatz 1877-1956 : [in conjunction with the exhibition "Paul Bonatz 1877-1956. Life and Building between Neckar and Bosporus", January 22 to March 20, 2011, hosted by the German Architecture Museum; second station of the exhibition: Kunsthalle Tübingen, March 26 to May 22, 2011] ¤ The companion book to the exhibitions "Paul Bonatz 1877-1956. Life and Building between Neckar and Bosporus" at the German Architecture Museum in Frankfurt am Main from January 21 to March 20, 2011 and at the Kunsthalle Tübingen from March 26 to May 22, 2011. - - The richly illustrated and annotated catalog presents Paul Bonatz, one of the influential architects and architecture teachers of the 20th century, who left a diverse work between modernity and tradition between the Empire and the early Federal Republic. He also made a name for himself as a designer of technical buildings. Like few other architects, he managed a fruitful dialogue with the engineers. - Bonatz was a liberal cosmopolitan, his relationship to National Socialism was accordingly reserved. Nevertheless, he sought state commissions in the 1930s, which he also received. Although he held a influential position as a bridge designer in the construction of the autobahns, he criticized Hitler's gigantism and emigrated to Turkey in 1944, where he worked as an architect and professor for ten years. His most important building, the Stuttgart main station (1911-1927), is acutely threatened in the framework of the large project "Stuttgart 21" - the two side wings will be sacrificed

Europe on the way to the most competitive and dynamic economic space in the world? : an interim balance of the Lisbon Strategy ¤ Am 4. and 5. December 2003, the Hamburg Institute of International Economics (HWWA) and the Working Group European Integration jointly organized an interdisciplinary conference on European economy and economic policy in Hamburg. (Information from the foreword)
Medical Image Processing 2007: Algorithms – Systems – Applications Proceedings of the Workshop from March 25–27, 2007 in Munich ¤ In recent years, the workshop

Social Exclusion through Inclusion : Imprisonment and Offender Support between Restriction and Resocialization ¤ The combination of increasingly harsh criminal policy and restrictive social policy, as it is currently staged, has a socially excluding character in its interaction for marginalized groups. In connection with the increasing poverty, social exclusion has become an important topic in recent years. A growing number of long-term unemployed, the precarious living conditions of migrants in the metropolises, the increasing poverty among young people, all this points to social situations that are marked by the term social exclusion. The logic of such social processes: The less competitive, the more socially vulnerable, the more lawless and the more economically and socially dispensable, the greater the danger of social exclusion of morally degraded persons or groups. A group that unites several of these characteristics is that of people who have become offenders.

Functional Safety : Real-Time 2013 ¤ Foreword -- Sensor Networks -- Operating Systems and Middleware -- Multi-Core Programming -- Mobile Systems -- Engineering -- Modeling and Simulation -- Current Applications -- Education. With its 2013 workshop on the topic "Functional Safety", the Real-Time Systems Committee offers scientists, users, and manufacturers a forum where new trends and developments in the following programmatic focus areas are presented: Sensor Networks, Operating Systems and Middleware, Multi-Core Programming, Mobile Systems, Engineering, Modeling and Simulation. Reports on current applications and education complete the publication.

Public Financial Flows and Spatial Development : [Scientific Plenary Session 2008] ¤ With the topic of "Public Financial Flows and Spatial Development", the Academy for Spatial Research and Land Planning (ARL) addresses questions whose far-reaching and lasting political significance is undisputed and whose current appearance is repeatedly brought to the forefront of public interest in changing forms. Spatial effects arise from all financial policy measures, including those that do not have an explicit spatial development policy reference. Nevertheless, the spatial implications of financial policy decisions are often not incorporated into political decision-making procedures and the spatial consequences of political decisions are not sufficiently systematically analyzed and evaluated. In this context, the present volume offers exemplary studies and regionalized analyses as well as theoretical considerations on the spatial effects of public funding and use in a broad spectrum of current economic and financial policy fields. With the publication, the ARL aims to promote the scientific and political discourse in the interface between spatial research and financial science and to intertwine both with each other.

Fifth German IPv6 Summit 2012 ¤ On November 29 and 30, 2012, the 5th German IPv6 Summit 2012 took place at the Hasso-Plattner-Institute for Software Systems Technology GmbH in Potsdam, as documentation of which this technical report serves. Like the previous national IPv6 summits, the German IPv6 Council also pursued the goal of the 5th summit, which stood under the motto

The Human Right to Education and its Implementation in Germany: Diagnoses - Reflections - Perspectives ¤ The eleven authors share the standpoint that education decisively determines life chances and the conviction that education justice is to be established. With their research, they pursue the goal of systematically grounding the human right to education and formulating standards for a political implementation in an education social policy.

Contributions to the Göttingen Environmental Historical Colloquium 2009 - 2010 ¤ This annual yearbook presents essays in environmental history based on lectures given at the Göttingen study group “Environmental History” by external authors. As previous yearbooks it is dedicated to the plurality of approaches in environmental history and serves as a valuable source for information about current research in that realm

Sustainability in Science: Leopoldina Workshop on November 12, 2012 in Berlin ¤ At the center of global considerations for addressing the central challenges of the 21st century is the concept of sustainability. In order for this principle to be reflected in concrete action proposals, it requires specification. The book therefore examines sustainability in science, the most important source of information for society. In this context, sustainability is considered both in terms of structures and activities in research and teaching. The topics treated are "the research of sustainability", which is intended to provide strategies for a better understanding, the complex "sustainably researching", which analyzes the prerequisites, courses, and consequences of research according to the criteria of sustainability, and "the sustainability of research", which examines the essential principles of science - such as the falsifiability of its results - in the light of the idea of sustainability. The focal points of the analysis are, in all areas, on the one hand, the tension between the freedom and sustainability of science, and on the other hand, the effects of the debate on the structures of the science system.

Housing for All?! : Perspectives on Planning, Politics, and Architecture ¤ Housing prices and rents have been rising for years - especially in growing cities and regions of Germany. Affordable housing is becoming increasingly scarce, and lower and middle-income groups are particularly burdened by high housing costs.0This volume brings design, social, and political solution approaches into dialogue. The contributions explore the reasons for the return of the housing question and present strategies for creating affordable housing for all. Actors from science, practice, politics, and social movements find current perspectives on a pressing urban problem here

Capital Region Berlin-Brandenburg in Polish-German Dialogue : [Eighth DPAG Work Meeting on 18 and 19 September 1995 in Kazimierz Dolny/Vistula] ¤ The publication contains the results of the eighth work meeting of the German-Polish Working Group (DPAG) of the Academy as well as an information forum at the end of 1995 in Warsaw. The focus is on the development of Berlin and its spatial economic effects for Poland and Germany in Europe. In detail, the basics and perspectives of joint regional planning for the metropolitan region of Berlin-Brandenburg as well as the regional structural change and the control opportunities in the region are reported and discussed from the perspective of the metropolis Berlin. From a Polish point of view, the metropolis is considered under political, spatial planning, economic, and social aspects. Furthermore, considerations for the redesign of Berlin's city center as well as the major infrastructure projects of the federal capital are presented and discussed, as well as the role of Berlin in the system of large German cities is critically reflected. In addition, it is about the perspectives for the development of east-west traffic between Poland and Germany.

Landes- und Regionalplanung in Baden-Württemberg : a mid-term balance on the occasion of the 100th meeting of the LAG Baden-Württemberg ; [joint event of the ARL and the Ministry of Economics of Baden-Württemberg on July 10, 2008 at the House of Economy Stuttgart] ¤ In the year 2008, the Landesarbeitsgemeinschaft Baden-Württemberg of the Academy for Regional Research and Regional Planning celebrates its 100th meeting. The present volume, published on the occasion of this jubilee, draws a mid-term balance on the development of regional and state planning in Baden-Württemberg and presents the work, development, and essential characteristics of the Landesarbeitsgemeinschaft Baden-Württemberg.

Berlin - Innovations for the Renovation Case ¤ With contributions by Harald Wolf, Klaus Brake, Kurt Geppert, Martin Gornig, Peer Pasternack, Volkmar Strauch, Dieter Scholz, Vincent-Winnetou Sosa, Benjamin-Immanuel Hoff, Ines Wallrodt, Thomas Langeheiniken, Christian Kilger, Raphael Jung, Christian Meyer zu Schwabedissen, Ursula Westphal, Heidi Knake-Werner, Hermann Schulte-Sasse, Hans Jochen Brauns u.a

Cork : History, Architecture, Design 1750 - 2002 ; [for the special exhibition "Totally Corked?!" Cork: History, Architecture, Design 1750 - 2002 of the Museums of the City of Delmenhorst on the Nordwolle from 16.6. to 15.9.2002] ¤ For centuries, the renewing bark of the cork oak tree has provided valuable material for the production of bottle corks in countries around the Mediterranean. However, the commercial processing of cork has been located in the northwest of Germany, around and in the city of Delmenhorst, since the mid-18th century. Since then, the so-called "Proppensnieder" have mainly shipped cork stoppers to wine merchants all over the world. Cork has been and continues to be used in a wide variety of ways in architecture, design, and fashion: Cork has been used as a high-quality insulating material in building construction since ancient times; it is also highly sought after as a floor covering, either pure or as a main component of linoleum. Less well known is the fact that cork has been used for architectural model-making in Italy and Germany since the 18th century. It is also surprising that cork - alongside lacquer or leather - was used as a modern material in contemporary design in the 1920s, particularly in the avant-garde furniture design of Eileen Gray. The book deals with the cultural and social history of cork production and the cork industry, as well as the various uses of cork in architecture, design, and fashion of our time.

Breitband-Perspektiven : faster access to innovative applications ; with 137 illustrations and 7 tables ; [Expert conference "Breitband-Perspektiven - Faster Access to Innovative Applications" of the Munich Circle] ¤ Worldwide, the expansion of telecommunications networks to a broadband infrastructure is in full swing. DSL is the backbone of fast internet access in many countries. TV cables are increasingly used for fast internet access. For mobile participants, wireless access technologies offer additional solutions. DAB and DVB are used for the transmission of content and data; in third-generation cellular systems as well as in wireless LANs, non-voice services are in the foreground. The questions are: How does broadband pay off? What do business models look like? Who finances the expansion of the infrastructure? The Munich Circle has conducted a critical inventory of global efforts. Supported by high-ranking experts, the current developments and future prospects were analyzed. This book contains the results

Fourth German IPv6 Summit 2011 ¤ On December 1st and 2nd, 2011, the 4th German IPv6 Summit 2011 took place at the Hasso-Plattner-Institute for Software Systems Technology GmbH in Potsdam, the documentation of which this technical report serves. Like the previous national IPv6 summits, the German IPv6 Council also pursued the goal of the 4th summit, which stood under the motto

Proceedings of the Fall 2010 Future SOC Lab Day ¤ In cooperation with industry partners, the Hasso-Plattner-Institute (HPI) establishes the “HPI Future SOC Lab”, which provides a complete infrastructure of high-complex on-demand systems on the latest, not yet available on the market, massively parallel (multi-/many-core) hardware with enormous main memory capacities and corresponding software. The HPI Future SOC Lab has prototype 4- and 8-way Intel 64-Bit server systems from Fujitsu and Hewlett-Packard with 32- and 64-cores and 1-2 TB main memory. In addition, high-performance storage systems from EMC² and virtualization solutions from VMware are used. SAP provides its latest Business by Design (ByD) software and also complex real business data is available, which can be accessed for research purposes. Interested scientists from universities and non-university research institutions can investigate future high-complex IT systems in the HPI Future SOC Lab, develop new ideas/data structures/algorithms and pursue them up to practical testing. This technical report presents the first results of the research projects started in the context of the opening of the Future SOC Lab in June 2010. Selected projects presented their results on October 27, 2010, as part of the Future SOC Lab Tag event.

Diversity and Representation : Belonging and Exclusion in the Literature Museum and in Literary Studies ¤ The analysis and mediation of literary texts from the early 19th century holds diverse potential for dealing with diversity, belonging, and exclusion. The contributors ask how cultural diversity in museum and literary and educational science practice leads to critical reflections and new perspectives on canonical objects. At the center is the interest in the options for representing diversity in the literature museum and in literary studies. Furthermore, they bring together theoretical and practical approaches and develop a new methodically-theoretically diverse range.

Events and Fairs in the Digital Age: Current Status and Perspectives ¤ The authors of the conference proceedings discuss the impact of digitalization on live communication and provide explanations for the successful use of digital technologies in the event and trade fair industry. The book brings together the current research results on the topic of events and fairs in the digital age, which were presented and discussed at the 11th Scientific Conference on Event Research, held on October 25, 2019 at the TU Chemnitz. The focus theme is supplemented by practice-oriented contributions, including the use of marketing automation tools in agency practice or the current state of the use of event apps in the context of events and fairs. The content includes Virtual- and Augmented Reality in Live Communication Self-Service Technologies on Events and Fairs Marketing automation in the event and trade fair industry The target groups are lecturers and students of business sciences with a focus on marketing, sales, and communication Professionals and executives from the fields of event and trade fair management as well as marketing The editor Prof. Dr. Cornelia Zanger was the chair of the chair of marketing and business administration at the Technical University of Chemnitz from 1994 to 2020. Since her retirement, she has been leading the event research at the Technical University of Chemnitz. She is the initiator of the Scientific Conference on Event Research and editor of the series Marketing Communication and Relationship Marketing.

Stereospecific polymerization and stereoregular polymers : [International Symposium on "Stereospecific Polymerization and Stereoregular Polymers", EUPOC 2003] ; Milan, Italy, June 8 - 12, 2003 ¤ EUPOC 2003, the European Polymer Conference on "Stereospecific Polymerization and Stereoregular Polymers", held in Milan, Italy, was organized to celebrate the 100th birthday of Giulio Natta, who received the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1963 together with Karl Ziegler

Böhm: Fathers and Sons : Architectural Drawings by Dominikus Böhm, Gottfried Böhm, Stephan, Peter, and Paul Böhm ; an exhibition of the Kunsthalle Bielefeld and the Foundation for Art and Culture of the State of North Rhine-Westphalia ; [June 26 - August 14, 1994] ¤ Three generations of the architects' family: Dominikus Böhm ( - 1880-1955), Gottfried Böhm(1920-), Stephan (1950-), Peter ( - 1954-), Paul (1959-). - Includes 2 contributions: - Weisner, Ulrich: Three Architectural Generations : Dominikus - Böhm - Gottfried Böhm - Stephan, Peter, and Paul Böhm - Heinen, Werner: "I build what I believe" : Modern Church Buildings by Dominikus Böhm

What Connects Bits and Trees : Shaping Sustainable Digitalization ; Bits & Trees, the Conference on Digitalization and Sustainability, Technical University of Berlin in November 2018 ¤ The conference »Bits & Trees« (2018 in Berlin) offered the largest debate forum to date for digitalization and sustainability. More than 50 authors from the tech scene, the sustainability movement, and development cooperation show in this book on the conference how digitalization can drive social-ecological change. The contributions illuminate the effects of our digital consumption in the Global South, sustainable data management, or the risks and potential of a digitalized economic system. At the center is always the pressing question: Which digitalization do we want? The various answers to this question make it clear: A future-proof digitalization must orient itself less to the interests of individual economic actors, but to the common good. Selected contributions of »Bits & Trees« numerous infographics and portraits provide thought and action stimuli on how digitalization can make the world better

Diversity: History and Relevance of a Concept ¤ Introduction: Diversity and Science / Hans-Jörg Rheinberger -- The Multiplicity of Rock Types and the Logic of Mineralogical Taxonomies / Alexandre Métraux -- Breaks in the Ladder of Life: Diversity in the Natural History of 1758-1859 / Staffan Müller-Wille -- Capturing Biodiversity: From Soups and Satellites / Tahani Nadim -- Epistemic Diversity in the Age of Big Data: How Data Infrastructures Serve Biomedical Research / Sabina Leonelli -- Scientific Pluralism and Bio-Gerontology / Marcel Weber -- Introduction: Social Diversity / André L. Blum -- Genetic Diversity without Races: Conceptual Historical Considerations / Veronika Lipphardt -- Human Diversity from a Doctor's Perspective / André L. Blum -- Cultural Diversity: A Multifaceted Concept in the Mills of Reality / Joost Smiers -- Why All These Gods? On the Potentialities of Polytheism / Philippe Borgeaud -- Living with Biodiversity: The Role of Natural History Museums / Johannes Vogel -- Diversity in Public Art Collections / Hans Christoph von Tavel -- Introduction: Diversity and the Arts / Nina Zschocke -- Varied Thinking: Goethe's Elegy

Sacred Spaces in Judaism : Festschrift for Salomon Korn ¤ Architecture – Society – Religion: These are the coordinates of the Festschrift for the sociologist, architect, and chairman of the Frankfurt Jewish Community, Salomon Korn. ‚Sacred Spaces in Judaism‘ spans the arc from the architecture of the Temple through temple conceptions, virtual sacred spaces, prayer rooms to synagogues from the Middle Ages to classical modernity. The volume brings together contributions to a conference on the same topic from various departments of the Heidelberg University for Jewish Studies, whose chairman Salomon Korn was for many years, and includes studies by further researchers on the subject. As a result, it illustrates the surprising breadth of sacred space concepts in Judaism and highlights the Jewish contribution to the history of European sacred architecture.

JXTA Workshop - Potentials, Concepts, Applications ¤ The trend towards ubiquitous networking can be described with the terms pervasive Computing or Peer-to-Peer networks. This trend has led to a paradigm shift in the development of applications over the past few years. In this context, the support of networking of virtual organizational units or electronic devices is often discussed. With the JXTA technology, a suitable framework is available for realizing these visions. Peers connected to any networks recognize each other and can communicate directly with each other. This volume provides a documentation of current development projects in this field

Parallel Data Processing with the Transputer : 5th Transputer User Meeting TAT '93, Aachen, September 20-22, 1993 ¤ The contributions of the 5th Transputer User Meeting TAT '93 come from industry, research, development, and teaching and provide detailed information on the new possibilities of Transputer applications and performance improvements that can be achieved with this parallel computing technology. The topics of this volume are algorithms, neural networks, as well as image and real-time processing. It becomes clear that it is even possible with relatively small Transputer systems to solve tasks that were previously reserved for large computers. This book offers the beginner an overview of problems that can be successfully handled with the Transputer and the expert a wealth of suggestions and solution proposals based on successful Transputer applications

Biometrics in the reflections of requirement : Second BSI-Symposium on Biometrics 2004 ¤ Proceedings zum 2. BSI-Symposium on Biometrics am 1./2.März 2004 in Darmstadt. Dabei geht es um den Stand der Technik bei biometrischen Identifikationssystemen, die sowohl für Zwecke der Zutrittskontrolle als auch zur sicheren Identifizierung im Reiseverkehr zunehmend im Gespräch sind. Berichtet wird unter anderem über Pilotprojekte an den Flughäfen Frankfurt/Main und Sidney

Developments in Europe : Consequences for Regional Development in Bavaria ¤ The volume contains eight papers, which were presented at the 17th seminar for regional planners in Bavaria in October 1994. These deal with the current situation of regional development in Bavaria (1994) and with the global and European economic structural changes. They show, by example of the Netherlands, the Czech Republic, and Bavaria, the reactions in spatial planning to the new challenges and demonstrate the necessity, but also the limits, of a coordinated European spatial order.
Bildverarbeitung für die Medizin 2019 : Algorithms - Systems - Applications : Proceedings of the Workshop from March 17 to 19, 2019 in Lübeck ¤ In recent years, the workshop

Poverty Prevention through Debt Prevention: Empirical Findings, Methodological Approaches, and Perspectives ¤ The contributions of this collective volume deal with theories and models as well as approaches for the practice of debt prevention and poverty prevention. The authors examine how disadvantaged groups can be reached, they illuminate the relationships between poverty, indebtedness, and debt prevention, and they address the transfer of financial knowledge and financial competence to the target group of students and trainees. The book presents the current academic discourse on the practice of debt prevention in the German-speaking region and provides assistance to reflect on and further develop the work on this complex topic in a theory-guided manner. The content Debt and poverty as a subject of prevention and counseling Theories and concepts of prevention Methodological approaches and innovations Challenges and perspectives of debt prevention The target groups Lecturers and students of education, psychology, sociology, and social work Practitioners in social work The editors Dr. Christoph Mattes is a lecturer at the University of Applied Sciences for Social Work at the University of Applied Sciences Northwest Switzerland (FHNWS). His research focuses on poverty, indebtedness, life situation analysis, and methodical action in social work. Prof. Dr. Carlo Knöpfel is a professor of social policy at the University of Applied Sciences for Social Work at FHNWS. His research focuses on poverty, social policy, and social security, aging policy. Debt and poverty as a subject of prevention and counseling -- Theories and concepts of prevention -- Methodological approaches and innovations -- Challenges and perspectives of debt prevention.

Machine, Monument, Landmark : Historical Mills - Conflict over a Monument Category ; Conference of BTU Cottbus, 26./27. October 2001 ¤ *Weitere Angaben Sonstiges: (Auslfg: Mühlenvereinigung Berlin-Brandenburg e.V., Trebbiner Str. 9, 10963 Berlin)

Teleteaching : a new component in university teaching ¤ The volume brings together the contributions of the speakers to the conference "TeleTeaching as a component of the university teaching system", which took place on November 27 and 28, 1998 at the Friedrich Schiller University of Jena. The contributions reveal the various approaches and questions in the field of TeleTeaching/Telelearning and document the current state of the discussion. Some statements point to the future of related software and hardware development and are impulses for the further development of dynamic and network-based new learning environments. Content: General Orientation (Friedrich, Leonhard: Introduction - New learning and teaching in the horizon of cultural evolution. - Dahnke, Klaus: Telematic teaching systems in the interest horizon of education policy. Expectations and perspectives. - Koring, Bernhard: Internet and university development. - Ruhrmann, Georg: TeleTeaching from a media sociological perspective. - Junker, Markus: Copyright problems when using multimedia and internet in universities). - Technical Infrastructure (Irmscher, Klaus: Technical infrastructure and usage scenarios when using TeleTeaching. - Götz, Olaf: The technical platform of the TeleTeaching project in the framework of the Thuringian University of Applied Sciences. - Hogrefe, Dieter: TeleTeaching at the University of Lübeck). - Practice and Impulses (Bodendorf, Freimut/Klein, Arno: TeleTeaching applications and scenarios in economic education. - Zimmermann, Volker/Kraemer, Wolfgang/Milius, Frank: Virtual (Corporate) Universities - University knowledge for students and employees in the internet. - Kindiger, Susanne/Hendricks, Wilfried: TeleStudent - Innovative design of academic learning. - Adam, Peter: Teacher experiences with TeleTeaching in a study association of three universities. - Reppert, Gabriela: Internet-based self-study in the framework of TeleTeaching). - Evaluation (Dumont, Kitty: Results of the survey of lecturers from Thuringian universities and universities of applied sciences on the topic: TeleTeaching - an acceptable form of teaching? - Görke, Alexander: Evaluation of TeleTeaching). - Appendix (Pawlowski, Peggy: Possibilities of holistic learning through new information and communication technologies. - Bergmann, Harald: OCR systems in the service of creating electronic working materials) (HoF/Text adopted)

Atem. Gestalterische, ökologische und soziale Dimensionen ¤ During breathing - in the process of constant exchange and crossing of boundaries between the organism and its environment - air as an «immaterial» material becomes active. For the first time, this anthology brings together studies on breath from the perspective of the arts and humanities, as well as experimental scientific and design practices. Focusing on the period from 1900 to the present day, the publication covers an era during which air has become a precarious medium: whether in the context of climate change or global pandemic, space technology or gas warfare, air is now co-created and manipulated by humans. Against this backdrop, breath appears as an elusive yet vital substance that reveals the interconnections between the physical, symbolic, technological and social realms

Everyday and Transition Practices in Help for Young People : Between Self-Determination, Ingenuity and Societal Adaptation Demands ¤ Help for young people must be designed in such a way that they have a good chance at the end of the day of being able to live a self-determined life. What does everyday life in stationary aid institutions look like in order to achieve this goal? How can transitions be meaningfully designed? What social and legal policy decisions are necessary? In this volume, everyday and transitional practices in different help systems for young people are examined from different perspectives. This conference volume as a whole offers a variety of impulses for successful social pedagogical support for young people in transition situations on their way into adulthood. DZI-Social Work/ 7.2020

Mythos Monument : urban strategies in architecture and art since 1945 ; [refers back to an international conference held in January 2010 at the Institute of Art History at the Ruhr University Bochum under the title "Mythos Monument. Urban strategies in architecture and art since 1945"] ¤ The reflection of the monumental is a central theme of architecture as well as art since 1945. On the one hand, this is evident in attempts to renew modern architecture through a new understanding of concepts. On the other hand, art has been shaped since the 1960s by the desire to comment on or deconstruct the monumental self-awareness of architecture. - - The book shows how architecture and art enter into a complex dialogue, which can be observed on different levels: from the immediate confrontation in the urban space to the conception of utopian places and anti-monuments, and down to the critical commentary on destroyed or reconstructed buildings and monuments.

Quantitative Approaches in the Humanities : systematic and historical perspectives ¤ Since the beginning of the 19th century, quantitative methods have been applied in the humanities to describe, analyze, and interpret texts. Until the end of the 20th century, such approaches were underrepresented, but they have gained very strong importance in the context of Digital Humanities. The goal of the volume is to contextualize quantitative methods, on the one hand, theoretically, methodologically, and historically, and, on the other hand, to examine the significance of their results in the light of the digital present. In view of the innovative spirit of the Digital Humanities, it must not be forgotten that the idea of opposing a descriptive-analytical distant reading to an interpretative close reading is not much younger than the idea of close reading itself. For counting is by no means only conceivable through the 'digital revolution' of the humanities. Rather, what was determined by late Dilthey as the subject of the understanding and qualitatively oriented humanities has been explained as a 'measurable' object for about 200 years.

The New Century : European Time Diagnoses and Future Conceptions around 1900 ¤ This volume takes a look at the European-wide discussions and controversies around 1900. The contributions pay attention to the international dimension of these debates and focus on those fields of topics that contemporaries already gave special attention to and which were of prominent importance for the history of the 20th century. These included war and peace scenarios, scientific reasoning about a 'new man', perspectives on economy and technology, cultural and artistic determinations of location and future conceptions, expectations of a new gender order as well as the development of the industrial class society. These topics are illuminated from changing locations: from the perspective of social movements as well as from that of political classes, scientists or professional groups. 'Public opinion' of the turn of the century thus branches out into various actors and discussants. The book reconstructs a fascinating panoramic image of European public opinion - a panoramic image in which experiences of the past merge with expectations of the future, in which fears, distortions and omissions are just as suspended as hopes, longings and wishes.Ute Frevert is Professor of Social History at the University of Konstanz.

Model Germany : [the 34th Annual Conference of the Society for German Studies e.V., simultaneously the Symposium of the German Society e.V. ...] ¤ German studies have long taken a historical and contemporary dimension, which, before 1989, critically viewed existing conditions and, with regard to the GDR, always adopted a system-transcendent perspective. It was right to 'hope' for one Germany before 1989. From an economic point of view, Germany has already overcome the consequences of the division. The conference addresses the question of whether Germany can be called a model in the European and even global context, 23 years after reunification. For every social scientist, it is clear that the distinction between East and West remains the central distinction category in all areas. German studies will increasingly serve as a platform for perspectives and approaches that focus on a Germany that still perceives the division, reflects the successful integration in current and further historical retrospect, and begins to assume the status of a model.

Economic Buildings in the Ancient City: International Colloquium, November 16-17, 2012, Karlsruhe ¤ We are well informed about the economy of the ancient world. Buildings for the trade and money exchange were available in the cities, ranging from storage buildings in major economic centers and ports to bank and stock exchange buildings in the central squares of the cities. These buildings have been extensively studied by archaeologists and building historians, with building design and construction in the foreground. Economic historians have intensively dealt with trade and money transactions, without taking into account connections with buildings. Interdisciplinary cooperation opens up new perspectives. With the knowledge of economic processes, buildings can be better understood, and buildings can make economic processes visible. This became clear quickly during the first exchange of ideas between the different research disciplines. The present conference volume contains contributions on trade forms and trade relationships, it presents storage buildings and merchant houses and sheds light on the Magdalensberg in Carinthia, a major center of ore extraction and metal processing. A special place is taken by the Roman basilica as a great bank and stock exchange building, whose development began almost suddenly around 200 BC at the Roman Forum and with new standards also shaped the new power Rome as the center of the ancient economy and central authority of economic and tax law urbanistically. The two last contributions deal with the further development of the concept of basilica and its impact on church building and architectural theory to this day.

UK in View : Perspectives on Theories and Practice Fields in Supported Communication ¤ Supported Communication is no longer unthinkable in the everyday life of many people, regardless of the perspective from which one looks. The special and valuable thing about UK is precisely characterized by this multifacetedness: Different professions draw on different methods in unique ways in various life situations of those affected, in order to offer and promote additional or replacement forms of communication and thus meet the basic need for communication. The book brings together many different perspectives from which UK can be taken into view. Different methods are brought into view and different tools and approaches are taken under the magnifying glass. (Back book cover)

The Media of Architecture : an Exhibition of the A:AI Archive for Architecture and Engineering Art in North Rhine-Westphalia ; [November 21 to December 7, 2007, Rudolf-Chaudoire-Pavillon, Campus South, Technical University of Dortmund] ¤ When one hears of architecture, one thinks first of all of buildings. Yet, despite being surrounded by buildings on a daily basis, buildings that concern us are rarely present in the immediate moment. They are mostly conveyed to us in various ways: through images, models, texts, and other forms of representation. While the physical existence of buildings cannot be denied, no building can come into being, be used, and be understood without media. This was the subject of an exhibition at the Faculty of Civil Engineering at TU Dortmund, which was prepared and held by students. The range of architectural representation was shown using selected items from the holdings of the A:AI Archive for Architecture and Engineering Art in North Rhine-Westphalia. Once not organized by building projects, but by media, sketches, plans, perspectives, detail drawings, static calculations, models, photos, films, texts, and publications were presented. In doing so, the question was primarily pursued of which specific properties different media have, and what these properties can say about the essence of architecture in turn

B1|A40 - the beauty of the big street : a project in the urban space of A40 from Duisburg to Dortmund, 06.12.2010 - 08.08.2010 ; Atelier van Lishout; Finger ...  ; [in conjunction with the exhibition "B1|A40 The beauty of the big street. A project in the urban space of A40 from Duisburg to Dortmund"] ¤ Through its daily closure in July, the A 40 highway became the largest media event in the European Capital of Culture RUHR.2010. The exhibition "B1 | A40 - The beauty of the big street" reflects how the A 40, in a unique reversal, becomes the central boulevard of the Ruhr metropolis with its over six million inhabitants, moving from the periphery to the center. Community gardens and shopping miles, cultural production and shadow economy - they all use the "big street" as a platform, node, infrastructure. This situation offers the opportunity to investigate pressing questions of the "Urban Age" on site: How are spaces generated beyond targeted planning and use interests? And what characterizes these - largely invisible to planning and politics - spaces? Artists, scientists, planners, and residents report on the conditions and opportunities of the new (city-) landscape and give valuable impulses for the current urban development discourse between art and planning

Exhausting Work : Health and Prevention in the Flexible Work World ¤ The new work world is characterized by increasing uncertainty. Discontinuous employment relationships are further on the advance. For employees in the knowledge economy, this is connected with higher degrees of freedom, but also new burdens - up to burnout. In addition, job nomads, freelancers, and temporary workers are often excluded from occupational health promotion. How and by whom can these groups be supported in health prevention? - The book illuminates these questions from various social scientific perspectives and underpins the argumentation with empirical findings. The book illuminates these questions from various social scientific perspectives and underpins the argumentation with empirical findings.

Castles of Late Gothic in Central Germany : Conference Proceedings ; [from October 20 to 22, 2006, the symposium "Castles in the second half of the 15th century in Central Germany" ... took place at Sachsenburg Castle] ¤ Since 2002, investigations into the building history have been conducted at Sachsenburg Castle near Frankenberg/Sa. by the Sachsenburg Castle Foundation. The extremely significant findings obtained provided the occasion to hold a symposium on castle construction in the second half of the 15th century in Central Germany in 2006. This also made it possible to present the newly obtained research results in numerous other castles in Central Germany. This volume presents the contributions of the most renowned researchers in the field

Monument and Energy 2017 : Energy Efficiency, Sustainability and User Comfort ¤ Contributions from renowned authors explain the opportunities and risks of energetic reinforcement of the building envelope and show successful energetic renovations under consideration of monument protection through practical examples. Furthermore, detailed considerations on fire protection and economic efficiency as well as the latest findings from research and development are presented. The connection between monument protection and energy efficiency poses a great challenge to current monument conservation. In the long term, historic buildings cannot escape the conflict between energy-saving measures and the preservation of original building substance. In the sense of sustainability, it is necessary to reduce the energy consumption and emissions of these buildings without significantly changing their appearance. However, only if a historic building meets a certain level of user comfort, it can also be used for future purposes and thus preserved. The content Buildings and Projects - Design and Construction - Material and Technology - Research and Development The target groups Architects, engineers, monument conservators, and representatives of the public service and companies active in the field of monument conservation and renovation. The editors Prof. Bernhard Weller is Director of the Institute for Building Construction at the Technical University of Dresden. Dipl.-Ing. Sebastian Horn is head of the Research Group Energy Efficiency and Sustainability at the Institute for Building Construction of the Technical University of Dresden. Buildings and Projects -- Design and Construction -- Material and Technology -- Research and Development.

Terrorism as a Challenge to the European Union ¤ The fight against international terrorism has been a central focus of European security policy for over fifteen years. However, this raises the question of whether the large number of security measures and laws adopted at various political levels meet the required standards of effectiveness and proportionality. This volume offers a critical review of this policy area. In it, Raphael Bossong gives an overview of the strategic trends in EU anti-terrorism policy since 2015, while Oldrich Bures evaluates European measures to control so-called foreign fighters. Martin Kahl develops a fundamental critique of the effectiveness of the EU’s fight against terrorism. Tim Krieger and Daniel Meierrieks condense the economic debate on the cost and impact assessment of terrorism. Anja Jacobi and Janina Kandt analyse transnational governance to curb the financing of terrorism. With contributions byDr. Raphael Bossong, Prof. Oldrich Bures, Dr. Martin Kahl, Prof. Tim Krieger, Dr. Daniel Meierrieks, Prof. Anja Jacobi, Janina Kandt

Hochschuldidaktische Qualifizierung : Strategies and Concepts in International Comparison ¤ The academic didactics qualification belongs today to the international standard. More and more countries, whose main resource is education, rely on the didactic qualification of their teaching staff. The book describes the international status quo: current country examples show the far-reaching changes in this area. In Germany, in particular, study programs, networks, and increasingly also modularized programs of academic didactics institutions take up an important place

Artificial Intelligence, Democracy, and Privacy ¤ This volume contains selected papers from the 2021 annual conference affiliated to ‘Forum Privatheit’, which analyse the current challenges posed by the development of artificial intelligence (AI) to privacy, informational self-determination and democracy, and how they can be addressed through governance mechanisms. The contributions focus on the use of AI for profiling and surveillance purposes, on issues related to the dissemination and detection of disinformation through AI, and on the use of AI in the health and care sectors.

Environment and Empirical Social and Economic Research: Contributions and Discussion Reports from a Conference of the Project Group 'The Socio-Economic Panel' at the German Institute for Economic Research ¤ Environment and economic research and environmental protection are by no means only a subject of natural sciences, but empirical social and economic sciences and have an important place in this field of problems. The corresponding empirical research serves mainly two purposes: on the one hand, the representation (description) of the perception of the environmental status and its evaluation by the population and their subgroups. This branch of environmental social research stands in the tradition of social reporting. On the other hand, social and economic surveys serve the analysis of behavior, i.e., the investigation of the determinants of environmentally relevant behavior as well as the perception of the environment and its evaluation. -- The present volume provides an overview of environmentally oriented social and economic research in the first block. The second block contains essays that stand in the tradition of social reporting, while the third block presents investigations that micro-analytically examine environmental behavior

Digitization and the law ¤ New technologies mean new challenges for the law. The Internet is no longer a new land, critical issues such as cyber attacks, privacy, the protection of minors or cloud computing are not yet fully discussed. The increasing digitalization and technologization do not only concern the World Wide Web. Automated road traffic is a similarly forward-looking topic, whose development must be accompanied by law. In the present volume, research works by law scientists from Germany, the USA, Canada, and Greece are compiled. The series on Robotics and Law edited by Prof. Eric Hilgendorf and Prof. Susanne Beck deals with the discussion of practically relevant legal questions on robotics, technologization, and digitalization. With contributions from: Prof. Eric Hilgendorf, Prof. Susanne Beck, Prof. Mark Kende, Prof. Ari Ezra Waldman, Prof. Maria Kaiafa-Gbandi, Prof. Sara Sun Beale and Peter Berris, Prof. Frank Peter Schuster

The Quran and its Religious and Cultural Environment ¤ In research, the Quran is often viewed as a self-sufficient text. The participants of the colloquium on the Quran, held at the Historical College in May 2006, freed themselves from this view. The contributions brought together in this volume testify to the diversity of approaches and methods used to study the Quran. They reflect the diversity of disciplines that deal with the Quran, from theology to Oriental studies and literature.

Uncertainty Signatures of Technology: A New Interpretation of the Technified World ¤ Not that fundamental uncertainty has not always been a part of life or a more or less constant and universal condition of human existence, appears as a problem, but - that with the experience of an increase in uncertainty, technology is also affected and involved in the process of uncertainty; - that social freedom and option gains go hand in hand with lasting orientation losses; - that the technoscientific production of knowledge brings forth new zones of unknowing; - that we cannot know what we should actually do and - that dealing with this fact represents the starting condition for a time- and time-less philosophy of technology. The contributions of this volume (e.g. by Dreyfus, Dupuy, Hörning, Hubig, Nordmann and Willke) do not only follow the different aspects of this development. They also attempt to assess the socio-technical attempts at determination and clarification strategies, which in a radically modern world are always anew challenged by the task of 'self-determination in the uncertain' (Luhmann).

Believe against each other - research together? : Paradigm shift in early modern science cultures ¤ Den inhaltlich-thematischen Ausgangspunkt des Bandes bildet das sich verändernde Verhältnis von frühneuzeitlicher Astronomie und Physik zur christlichen Religion im Allgemeinen und zu ihren konfessionsspezifischen Ausprägungen im Besonderen. Vor diesem Hintergrund nehmen die versammelten Beiträge exemplarisch die entsprechenden, mit dem Wandel des Weltbildes verbundenen Prozesse anhand des zur Transkonfessionalität tendierenden Paradigmenwechsels in den frühneuzeitlichen Wissenschaftskulturen in den Blick. Dabei bieten die Welt, deren Bilder einen Wandel durchliefen, die Naturwissenschaften, die den Wandel vorantrieben, und die Theologien, die sich von einstigen Gewissheiten über Gott und Welt verabschiedeten, sich neu konstituierten und das Leben sowie die Naturforschung in der Frühen Neuzeit entscheidend mitbestimmten, eine dankbare Fläche für eine interkonfessionell vergleichende Untersuchung konfessioneller Spezifika.

Digital Transformation and Sustainability in the Global Financial Industry ¤ Despite some intensive discussions, there is still no conclusive nomenclature for the terms digital transformation and sustainability in the financial industry; their possible relationship has also remained largely unclear to date. However, there is general agreement that these terms and the changes behind them represent major challenges for companies and their stakeholders. This edited volume discusses the opportunities and risks arising from these two areas and their interplay, focusing in particular on both global finance and core financial aspects in companies. With contributions by Eduard Bossauer, Prof. Dr. Alexander Brink, Julia Brunhuber, Prof. Dr. Michel Charifzadeh, Nicolas Danninger, Prof. Dr. Manuela Ender, Alain Fuchs, Dr. Tim Herberger, Felix Hübner, Prof. Dr. Michael Kuttner, Prof. Dr. Christine Mitter, Jörg Müller, Maurice Niklos, Prof. Dr. Martina Sageder, Selina Somogyi, Jona Stinner, Marcel Tyrell, Jens Wiedra, Prof. Dr. Konrad Wimmer and Markus Wimpissinger.

Inquiring Women : Women Changing the Sciences ¤ The authors of this volume address the question of what significance women can achieve in the sciences. They exemplarily illuminate the life stories of contemporary women scientists such as Emmy Noether and Grace Murray Hopper. At the same time, they exercise science criticism in individual disciplines. They convey a current picture of the sciences and their institutions, in which women still have to contend with structural disadvantages. - Content: Ströker, Elisabeth: The role of women in the discovery of nuclear fission. - Tollmien, Cordula:

Social Media - New Masses : [... 2nd media scientific symposium of the German Research Foundation] ¤ At mass gatherings and the positive or negative phantasms of the mass, different discourses and practices of social control, communication, and community formation ignite. However, masses are no longer what they once were. From the replacement of mass media research by algorithmic evaluation of mass data to the diagnosis of scattered publics in the age of social media to new mass conceptions such as swarms, flash mobs, and multitudes: The emergence, functioning, and effects of digital masses are to be newly examined and negotiated. Furthermore, the changes of the present are an option to understand the culture and media history of the masses themselves anew. The book outlines this new field of research and brings together analyses of the difference between new and old masses, the different media-technical conditions, as well as the political consequences of current mass phenomena.

Communication and Image Processing in Automation : Selected Contributions of the Annual Conferences KommA and BVAu 2016 on the 10th Anniversary of the inIT - Institute for Industrial Information Technology ¤ In this conference volume, the best contributions of the 7th Annual Conference on

What Models Can Do: A Small History of the Architectural Model in Contemporary Art; [on the occasion of the exhibition What Models Can Do. A Small History of the Architectural Model in Contemporary Art, June 29 - October 12, 2014, Museum of Contemporary Art Siegen] ¤ The three-dimensional architectural model – in a reduced scale – has been and is a tool for communication in the field of architecture and urban planning, for planned or realized architecture. The model can efficiently provide information about larger spatial relationships, which one perceives differently or not at all in original size. Because the model allows for the reduction of spatial complexity through miniaturization. Suddenly, one can see with a glance what can only be experienced in the temporal process of bodily explorations piece by piece in original size. It is striking that in contemporary art, the architectural and urban model is frequently taken up and freed from its narrowly defined functional context, so that its primary phenomenological qualities are adapted and made fruitful for artistic questions. In the conceptually understood contemporary art of the last 40 years, the architectural model is poetically opened and used in a metaphorical and theatrical way. Important in this context is also the mysterious aura of the small, as Gaston Bachelard describes it: So the gaze can penetrate – almost bodiless, yet always relying on and trusting the bodily experience. On the one hand, the obvious reference to the architectural model helps with the development and solution of sculptural questions, on the other hand, the architectural model – precisely in its state, which always remains a draft and is to be realized – can serve as an instrument of criticism and illustration of utopia. Just the both-and, the simultaneity of direct sensory presence and the suggestive distance to the experiential space of the viewers, makes one of the fascinations of the model. The exhibition and the book start the attempt to write a small history of the architectural model in contemporary art. This should begin with the legendary – monumental – models of Charles Simonds and Anne and Patrick Poirier, with Ludger Gerdes, Hermann Pitz and Thomas Schütte to brush the 1990s and continue the thread to the current positions.

Myths of Creativity: The Creative Between Innovation and Hubris; [Contributions of the Volume ... originated from the International Symposium  ¤ Since the beginning of culture, human creative power has been addressed in myths and narratives. The

The Color White : Color Frenzy and Color Abstinence in Architecture ; [as Catalog for the Exhibition "The Color White - Color Frenzy and Color Abstinence in Architecture", April 27 - June 22, 2003, Ulm City Hall] ¤ Ten years after the completion of the city hall, the building itself was the focus of an exhibition, designed by Richard Meier. At the center was a characteristic of Meier's architecture, the emphatically presented white. With this white, Meier linked to the architecture of modernity around 1930. Here, white was associated with sobriety and clarity. It stood for the liberation from the shackles of history, from the pathos of the (colored) founder's era, which was felt to be outdated. - - At least since the early Renaissance, color has been used programmatically in architecture. The exhibition documented the change in attitudes through selected graphics, paintings, and architectural models, with the 19th and 20th centuries at the center. Works by Gottfried Semper, Jakob I. Hittorff, Giovanni Salucci, Friedrich von Gärtner, as well as Bruno Taut, Hans Scharoun, and Hermann Finsterlin were on display. The final point was made by works of contemporary architects like Sauerbruch Hutton, Otto Steidle, and Günther Behnisch, whose emphasized colorfulness contrasted with Richard Meier's white. - - The works on display were in and on colorful volumetric cubes, which, on the one hand, maintained a respectful distance from the walls of the city hall, and on the other hand, allowed the exhibition of light-sensitive graphics in their interior. The walls of the main exhibit, Richard Meier's architecture, were not touched by the exhibition, except for some programmatic quotes.

Resilience as a Success Factor in Tourism: Contributions from Science and Practice for the Development of Destinations ¤ This is an Open-Access book. Resilience is today one of the central future themes in tourism. Under the conditions of persistent crisis situations and rapid change processes, questions of resistance and adaptability are increasingly being brought to the forefront. What distinguishes more resilient destinations and tourist actors in more detail and how the necessary transformation of the industry succeeds, is investigated in this innovative volume. In addition to current practical insights from different regions, relevant topics are treated, such as: - the role of diversity, - resilience in destination management, - the importance of citizen participation, - the consideration of the perceptions of the local population, as well as - resilience in wine and hiking tourism. A fascinating impulse giver to a key theme of the tourism industry, which emerged in the framework of the „5th Deidesheimer Conversations on Tourism Science“.

Urban Extensions 1800 - 1875 : from the beginnings of modern urban planning in Germany ; [Results of the 1st colloquium on planning history, which took place with support and in the rooms of the Werner-Reimers Foundation in Bad Homburg from 7 to 10 December 1981] ¤ The urban planning of modern stamp set in after the princes of the country had lost their competence for the expansion of the cities and the social concerns of the citizens. In the early bourgeois era, roughly until the last quarter of the 19th century, the division and use of urban land was subject to a bitter competition between private landowners and increasingly also commercial land and construction companies. Between state and municipal institutions and private owners of land and property, new areas of responsibility, techniques, and design principles emerged. The new planning goals and building forms soon exacerbated the

Imitation in the Middle Ages: Dimensions - Mechanisms - Functions ¤ Imitieren : Mechanisms of a cultural principle in medieval Europe : an introduction / Gerald Schwedler and Jörg Sonntag -- Imitatio as a form of cultural action / Dina De Rentiis -- Imitation as a principle of teaching? Examples from 13th-century letter rhetoric / Florian Hartmann -- Imitation and topos. The Historia Sicula of Bartolomeo da Neocastro and the description of the fall of the city of Acre in 1291 / Jörg Schwarz -- The fine difference : imitation and its limits. Coronation of a king by the Pope, coronation of an emperor by the Pope / Andreas Büttner -- Rome in Avignon : imitation and adaptation in the papal palace / Melanie Brunner -- The civitas Dei, its perception and imitation in 12th-century exegesis / Irina Redkova -- Holy people as role models for spiritual women of the 14th and 15th centuries. A contribution to the imitatio sanctorum in the late Middle Ages / Regina D. Schiewer -- Same names, same essence. Practices of re-naming in late medieval Europe / Christof Rolker -- Altera Roma, soror Rome, Roma secunda. Roman comparison and Roman imitation north of the Alps during the Middle Ages / Lukas Clemens

When Dignity Becomes Commodity: Social Inequality, Participation, and Realization of a Right to Housing; [... Federal Congress of the Protestant Homeless Aid, which took place from November 17 to 19, 2012 in Nuremberg with the title "Housing is good - everything is good?".] ¤ In this volume, the difficulties of access to the general housing market for people are shown. This has no interest in housing provision for all on its own and is subject to other laws. Having to live without a home means not only being deprived of fundamental rights, but also having to defend oneself against various prejudices. The excluded often have different cultural backgrounds or have to struggle with psychological difficulties. Different models of accompanying counseling for stabilizing living conditions are presented, as well as cooperation forms with neighboring fields of work in homeless aid. The content Political and legal conditions Methodical approaches to fair housing provision Accompanying counseling and cooperation forms in homeless aid The target groups Lecturers and students of social, educational, and political science Practitioners in homeless aid, politicians The editors Stefan Gillich is deputy chairman of the Protestant Homeless Aid in Germany e.V. and head of the department of Existence Security, Poverty Policy, Community Diakonia at the Diakonie Hessen - Diakonisches Werk in Hessen and Nassau and Kurhessen-Waldeck e.V., Frankfurt. Rolf Keicher works at the Diakonie Deutschland - Evangelischer Bundesverband as a representative for help in special life situations and housing policy, Berlin

Status and Development of Water Education ¤ What methodical and conceptual approaches to water education there are, where which models are implemented, what makes the fascination of water in all its states of aggregation for humans, this is answered by the present NNA report both scientifically founded and visually oriented to implementation. The content spectrum of the volume ranges from a contribution on the cultural and spiritual significance of water, a water education project at an elementary school and the first water school garden to water guide training in Baden-Württemberg.[...] (Source: NNA)

Martin Elsaesser and the New Frankfurt : [within the framework of "Phenomen Expressionism 2009 - 2011 - a project of the Cultural Fund FrankfurtRheinMain" ; on the occasion of the exhibition "Martin Elsaesser and the New Frankfurt" (October 10, 2009 - March 14, 2010), organized by the German Architecture Museum, Department of Culture and Science, City of Frankfurt am Main] ¤ The accompanying book to the exhibition at the German Architecture Museum in Frankfurt am Main from October 10, 2009 to January 31, 2010. - - The publication assumes a dual role: it accompanies an exhibition and documents in detail realized and project-based buildings of the architect during his time as artistic director of the building authority in Frankfurt between 1925 and 1932. Furthermore, it deepens aspects such as Elsaesser's difficult role as a key co-designer of the New Frankfurt as well as the economic, political, and personal conditions of his tenure. The book also approaches the teacher and (family) person Elsaesser and undertakes excursions into other creative phases of the building artist, who has left a rich work before and a few, but outstanding, buildings after the Frankfurt phase. The analysis of his writings reflects the design understanding of a practitioner and theorist who understood himself as a mediator between tradition and modernity. In addition, the most comprehensive work catalog of his (re-)buildings and designs for Frankfurt between 1925 and 1954 is added.

Altar Space as Community Space: Renovation of Existing Churches; [a symposium held at the Catholic Theological Private University of Linz in May 2003] ¤ The renovation of existing churches, in particular altar space designs, have - following the boom of new buildings from the post-war period to the 1980s - become the most frequent undertaking of ecclesiastical building activity. Despite new insights into historical spatial situations and new liturgical-theological considerations, the ever new challenge for the communities remains to implement theological fundamental insights and pastoral requirements appropriately into a spatial design. A symposium held in May 2003 at the Catholic Theological Private University of Linz/Donau brought together experts from the fields of architecture, monument conservation, art, liturgy, and pastoral care

Efficiency and Effectiveness of Medical Diagnosis: Report on a Symposium of the International Society for Health Economics, Mainz; 16 Tables ¤ Hans Rüdiger Vogel (Ed.): "Efficiency and Effectiveness of Medical Diagnosis". A symposium of the International Society for Health Economics, Gustav Fischer Verlag, Stuttgart 1985, 132 pages with 68 figs. and 16 tables, 36 Marks

Making Heimat. Germany arrival country : atlas of refugee housing : Refugee Buildings Atlas ¤ The refugee situation in autumn 2015 was the starting point for the strongly discussed exhibition Making Heimat. Germany, Arrival Country in the German Pavilion at the 15th Architecture Biennale 2016 in Venice. The Refugee Buildings Atlas expands the considerations on the German arrival cities from the first volume. What role do architects and urban planners play in implementing sustainable solutions for the accommodation of newcomers in Germany? Which building projects can serve as prototypes for affordable housing? Based on about 55 building projects, a look into the future of German cities is taken. Photographs by Anja Weber and detailed project presentations, which arose from visits on site, provide insights into the daily life of German refugee accommodations

Information Age Economy : 5th International Conference on Business Informatics 2001 ¤ The use of information and (tele-)communication systems for business has become an ubiquitous phenomenon due to the rapid technological progress at the beginning of the 3rd millennium. Under keywords such as e(lectronic)-, m(obile)-, u(biquitous)-Computing/Commerce, today's visions of the future are discussed, which assign a central role to information and communication systems far beyond their current purposes on the way to electronic service economy. This book considers this development in all its facets and presents pioneering research and practice works at the interface of modern business administration, business informatics, and applied computer science. It bridges the gap between science and practice by showing the essential design options and recommendations that pave the way for businesses to successfully enter the "Information Age Economy"

Variants of Change : the Region in Recent History 1970-2020 ¤ It may be surprising that 'great processes' like globalization or digitalization have brought the region back into the focus of historical interest. However, it was here that social changes 'after the boom' were actually most evident. In view of the transformative quality of these years, research now distinguishes winners and losers and refers to significant regional differences. The authors of the volume take this as an opportunity to examine a series of different regional fields of study in more detail and to work out special 'variants of change' since 1970. It shows that acute action requirements below the national level were often recognized early on and that the social groups and actors on site proved to be the actual shapers of change. The regions were, however, affected to varying degrees due to their respective dispositions and potentials and therefore followed in many cases very specific development paths.

The Education of the Future ¤ It is undisputed that our education system needs to be reformed. However, how and in what way, is a matter of debate. What competencies should be taught, which overarching aspects should guide the process, and in what form should the goals be implemented? The book offers a comprehensive compendium on the following three topics: educational goals, reform of educational institutions, and requirements for the economy and politics. Content: Lepenies, Wolf: Education Pathos and Reality of Education. - Ludwig, Volker: Three Songs. - Wilson, Robert: Something about Learning to Learn. - Ammann, Jean-Christophe: Reading in Images and Thinking in Images. - I. EDUCATIONAL GOALS. - I.1 Dealing with Knowledge (Stadler, Arnold: From the Learned Circle to the Expert Team. - Fried, Johannes: Competition Creates Knowledge. - Burke, Peter: The Knowledge Society. - Grimm, Dieter: State and Knowledge). - I.2 Values and Education (Demski, Eva: Good Old Times. - Joas, Hans: Values and Experience. - Lehmann, Karl: Values! - Nunner-Winkler, Gertrud: Moral Change - Moral Learning). - I.3 Science and Responsibility (Muschg, Adolf: Morality has to do with Manners. - Bauman, Zygmunt: Science, Economy, and Responsibility. - Rajewsky, Klaus: Scientific Responsibility. - Nüsslein-Volhard, Christiane: Program Research and Freedom of Decision. - Thierse, Wolfgang: Science and Politics). - II. REFORM OF EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTIONS. - II. 1. Early Childhood Education (Ludwig, Volker: Children Need Theater. - Singer, Wolf: What Can Children Learn? - Elschenbroich, Donata: What Children Learn in Other Countries. - Rauh, Hellgard: Learning Early Without Compulsion. - Ahnen, Doris: Early Childhood Education in Transition). - II.2 School Education (Bohm, Hark: Images of Teachers. - Baumert, Jürgen: Transparency and Responsibility. - Bruggen, Johan C. van: The Dutch Model. - Schavan, Annette: The Importance of School and Education in Society). - II.3 University (Dell, Christopher: For a Technology of Improvisation. - Mittelstraß, Jürgen: University as a Way of Life. - Tenorth, Heinz-Elmar: Autonomy of the University, Cultivation of Knowledge. - Weiler, Hans N.: Observations of an American Neighbor. - Schipanski, Dagmar: Interdisciplinarity as a Scientific Model. - Zöllner, Jürgen: The Price of Freedom is Responsibility). - II.4 Continuing Education (Nagel, Ivan: Continuing Education. - Mandl, Heinz: On the Way to a New Continuing Education Culture. - Pl...

Instrumentarium of Spatial Planning and State Planning for Raw Materials Security in the States of Bremen, Hamburg, Lower Saxony, and Schleswig-Holstein ¤ The state of implementation of raw materials security in Lower Saxony and Schleswig-Holstein, from state and regional planning to the municipal level, is considered from a geological-economic and planning perspective. Weaknesses in raw materials economic demand analysis as well as in the planning implementation of the respective area allocations (priority, precaution, and reservation areas) are shown. The existing instrumentarium of state planning is sufficient. However, awareness of what binding planning provisions are and where scope for discretion lies is not sufficiently developed. Trustworthy cooperation of all parties involved in raw materials security is required in order to do justice to both nature and environmental protection and the supply of the economy with the necessary mineral raw materials.

The Late Echo of War Childhoods : The Consequences of World War II in Life Courses and Contemporary History ; [On February 22 and 23, 2013, in Münster ... the 2nd International Congress on the topic "Childhoods in Europe during World War II" took place] ¤ Expert professionals address war-related physical, psychological, and social burdens of the war children's generation. Above all, it is about the possible late consequences in old age, when childhood and youth were shaped by war burdens

Digital Transformation of the Public Sphere: Interdisciplinary Perspectives on Political Participation in Flux ¤ Widely discussed phenomena like ‘filter bubbles’ and ‘social bots’ point to the reality that the digital transformations of the present also encompass public communication. New opportunities for information and participation have arisen and opinion formation is changing. This volume explores these transformations from an ethical perspective and discusses theoretical work in theology, media ethics and political science in combination with digital practice. It evaluates the potential knowledge arising from various concepts and functions in the ‘public sphere’ under the conditions of digital societies, and discusses in a nuanced way both the dangers to democracy and the opportunities for civic participation and bottom-up processes as a result of digital transformation. Venturing beyond institutional politics, this volume explores the digital transformation of the political and its consequences for churches, protest movements and media outlets.Hence, the contributions it contains are not only relevant for academics working on digital transformation, but also journalists, politicians and employees at NGOs and in churches.With contributions bySigrid Baringhorst, Christina Schachtner, Florian Stickel, Julian Zeyher-Quattlender, Gary Schaal, Ilona Nord, Christoph Bieber, Jonas Bedford-Strohm, Alexander Filipovic, Alexander Görlach, Torsten Meireis, Frederike van Oorschot, Thomas Renkert.

Caravan of Hope : with Islam against pain and silence ; with the current results of the TARGET scholars' conference in Cairo ¤ With their human rights organization TARGET and the Pro-Islamic Alliance, Rüdiger Nehberg and Annette Weber fight against the barbarity of female genital mutilation. The >>Caravan of Hope<< has success: Sultans and Sheiks follow Nehberg's vision and declare the cruel practice a sin. For many girls, a new future begins. The impressive balance sheet of TARGET, crowned by a conference with the highest-ranking Muslim scholars in the world in Cairo. With their human rights organization TARGET and the Pro-Islamic Alliance, Rüdiger Nehberg and Annette Weber fight against the barbarity of female genital mutilation. The ?Caravan of Hope? has success: Sultans and Sheiks follow Nehberg's vision and declare the cruel practice a sin. For many girls, a new future begins. The impressive balance sheet of TARGET, crowned by a conference with the highest-ranking Muslim scholars in the world in Cairo

The Modulor : Mass and Proportion : LeCorbusier Pavilion ¤ The Modulor is perhaps Le Corbusier's most famous invention. Developed from examples in nature and art history, this last major proportion system combines the human scale with the Golden Section. From 1945, the Modulor becomes the basis for spectacular designs by Le Corbusier in graphic design, architecture, and urban planning, and ultimately a symbol of his universal achievement. This publication illustrates his passionate research, shows examples, references, and well-known applications.

Current Tasks for State and Regional Planning in Bavaria: 23rd Seminar for State and Regional Planners in Bavaria ¤ The 23rd Seminar for State and Regional Planners in Bavaria deals with various aspects that have become increasingly important for planning and will continue to grow. The first keyword is Europe, whose further integration must also affect state and regional planning. Especially at the regional level, it is challenges such as large retail projects or wind energy use and finally social change, which require more cooperation and collaboration at the regional level. In this context, new 'soft' planning instruments play an important role on the one hand, and changes in communication networks based on modern IuK technology on the other hand. The book provides a snapshot of the current discussion on the tasks and solution paths of current state and regional planning.

Software-intensive distributed Real-Time Systems : Conference of the GI/GMA-Committee Real-Time Systems (real-time) Boppard, November 19th and 20th, 2009 ¤ Communication in distributed real-time systems -- A framework for real-time capable Ethernet networks -- UniLoG — A system for distributed load generation in networks -- Planning of Time Triggered Communication Schedules -- Engineering tools for real-time systems -- Space-Time Constraints as programming abstraction for applications in mobile distributed systems -- Formal determination of system parameters for transparent scheduling of virtual machines under real-time conditions -- Resource management methods -- Application of methods of logistics and network planning for precedence- and resource-constrained scheduling of real-time systems -- Bee-inspired street traffic routing -- Student contributions -- Cross-layer detection of connection failures in wireless mesh networks -- Concept for data transfer in distributed real-time systems via Ethernet -- Real-time capability of the VxWorks network stack -- Manufacturing applications -- Communication requirements for distributed real-time systems in manufacturing automation -- XML-based product and process data for control technology design -- Lightweight configurable hardware abstraction layer for flexible automation -- Performance analysis and debugging -- Universal hybrid system observer for real-time systems -- Real-time behavior through the use of CPU stubs: An extension of dynamic performance stubs -- Protocol analysis and information flow tracking for fault diagnosis in distributed real-time systems.
